Graphical abstract Although the oxidation processes mediated by persulfate (PS) and peroxymonosulfate (PMS) attract more attention in the degradation of various recalcitrant contaminants, the high concentrations of oxidants required for the low concentrations of contaminants always limit their large-scale applications. In this work, aniline can be effectively oxidized by CuO and PS under pH-neutral and alkaline conditions. The increased observed rate constant (k obs) values with increasing pHs indicate that the oxidation of aniline is facilitated by solution OH−. Meanwhile, the low ratios between the removed PS and aniline (1.19 at pH 7.0 and 1.68 at pH 12.0) indicate the high catalytic oxidation efficacy of the CuO-PS system. The insignificant contributions of SO4 −, OH, 1O2 and O2 − to aniline oxidation in quenching experiments and EPR analysis suggest that PS is likely activated on the surface of CuO via the non-radical pathway. The presence of carbon-centered radicals (CCRs), as well as UV and GCMS analysis, indicates the important intermediates of PhNH2 + and PhNH radicals during the oxidation process, revealing that separate transfer of an electron from aniline to the activated PS, followed by subsequent abstraction of a H+ by OH− to form PhNH are two important steps in the oxidation process. Further coupling of PhNH radicals results in the formation of insoluble polyaniline polymers at pHs 7.0 and 12.0. The high thermal stability and ideal pseudo-capacitive properties of the insoluble products indicate that the polyaniline produced from aniline wastewater can be used for high-temperature-resistant materials or capacitors. This study provides an efficient alternative to turn aniline waste to polyaniline polymers. Keywords Waste recovery Aniline Contaminant Polyaniline Non-radical mechanism Persulfate 1 Introduction Anilines are a group of toxic contaminants extensively distributed in wastewater discharged from chemical industries such as antioxidant, dye, rubber, pharmaceutical industries [1,2]. Due to the high toxicities of anilines to living organisms, they are classified as persistent organic pollutant by US Environmental Protection Agency [3,4]. Although aniline contaminants can be mineralized into CO2 and H2O by OH, (E° = 1.8–2.7 V) [5,6] (eg. Fenton and Fenton-like reagents), the high costs for oxidants and rapid decreases of the redox potential of OH with increasing pHs always make those OH-based technologies not cost-effective for large-scale applications under alkaline conditions [6–8]. In addition, various methods such as ozone oxidation [9], nanofiltration and ultrafiltration separation [10], as well as biological methods have also been attempted to remove aniline from industrial wastewater [11]. However, drawbacks of high costs, membrane fouling and the high toxicity of aniline to microorganisms always limit their extensive applications in aniline wastewater [12–14]. How to more efficiently oxidize aniline wastes under alkaline conditions is therefore an interesting topic in the treatment of aniline wastewater. Persulfate (PS) is an emerging oxidant (E0 = 2.01 V) and shows high oxidation reactivity towards various recalcitrant organics [15,16]. The oxidizing SO4 − (E0 = 2.5–3.1 V) and OH generated during PS activation can non-selectively oxidize or even completely mineralize phenolic pollutants through hydroxylation and opening of benzene ring [17–21]. However, with increasing concentrations and carbon atoms of organic contaminants, the amounts of oxidants for fully mineralization will be significantly increased, resulting in the enhancement of the operating costs as well. In addition, more toxic intermediates generated in the oxidation of phenol by OH (such as hydroquinone and benzoquinone) also bring about more harmful threats to environmental ecology [22]. Apart from producing oxidizing radicals, PS can also directly oxidize aniline via the Boyland-Sims pathway with the formation of 2,4-sulfate aniline and 2,6-sulfate aniline [23]. In addition, non-radical activation of PS is another important pathway. CuO is a p-type semiconductor with monoclinic crystal structure and shows great potential in gas sensors, catalysis, batteries, high temperature superconductors and solar energy conversion [24,25]. For instance, Yang et al. [26] fabricated a facile non-enzymatic sensor using CuO microtubes as electrocatalytic active materials for electrochemical detection of glucose. Zhang et al. [27] suggested that the surface intermediate generated between PS and CuO was the predominant oxidizing species in 2,4-dichlorophenol oxidation in the pH range of 4.2–8.0, whereas SO4 − and OH were not. Our recent study also suggested that the non-radically activated PS by CuO could effectively turn thiophene to polythiophene S,S-dioxide products at pH 7.0 [28]. By means of the density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we further revealed that the OO bond in PS was moderately elongated when PS was adsorbed on the surface of Co3O4 rod(110), and the activated OO abstracted H atom from phenol to form phenoxyl radical [29]. Therefore, selective oxidation of aniline contaminants to polyaniline (PANI) seems to be an up-and-coming approach for treating aniline wastewater. In addition, PANI is a group of functional polymer materials with high conductivity and good thermochemical properties [30,31]. Actually, ammonium persulfate (APS) has also been used to homogeneously synthesize PANI in HCl solution [32]. In this reaction, the aniline monomers are transformed to aniline dimers after losing 1e and 1H+ separately, and then to trimers, oligomers and PANI polymers [33–36]. However, till now, direct production of PANI from aniline wastewater has not been reported yet. Moreover, the large amount of APS and the strict acidic conditions involved in the synthesis of PANI always make it inappropriate to treat alkaline aniline wastewater. As to the pH of aniline-containing wastewater is always high [37], we hypothesize that polymerization of aniline contaminants to valuable PANI polymers can also be achieved by PS and CuO under alkaline conditions. In this study, the objectives of are to (i) explore the oxidation efficacy of CuO and PS in aniline oxidation in pH-neutral and alkaline environments, (ii) characterize the soluble and insoluble oxidation products and reveal the corresponding oxidation mechanisms, and then (iii) investigate the electrochemical properties and thermostability of the insoluble products obtained under different pH conditions. 2 Experiments 2.1 Materials The reagents of K2S2O8, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, KI, NaHCO3, NaNO2, H6N2O3S, KHSO4, aniline, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP), 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-4-piperidone (TMP), tetrahydrofuran (THF), tert-butyl alcohol (TBA), 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrrolidine N-oxide (DMPO), dimethylfumarate (DMF), tetrahydrofuran (THF), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) and dimethyl sulfoxide-d6 (DMSO-d6 ) were all analytical grade and purchased from Aladdin Chemical Company (Shanghai, China). N-(1-naphthyl)-ethylenediamine dihydrochloride (C12H14N2·2HCl) was purchased from Guangfu Fine Chemical Engineering Institute (Tianjin, China). 2.2 Characterizations of the synthesized CuO nano-rods The CuO nanorods used in this study were synthesized using the method described previously [28]. The synthesized CuO shows the characteristic peaks of (110), (002), (111), (20−2), (020), (202), (11−3), (113), (220), (311) and (22−2) planes in XRD analysis (JCPDS, No. 48-1548) (Fig. S1), and exhibits nano-rod morphology in SEM analysis (Fig. S2a) with the BET surface area of 26.22 m2 g−1. 2.3 Oxidation kinetics The oxidation experiments were carried out in 250 mL Erlenmeyer flasks in the dark. In a general procedure, 50 mL CuO suspension, 50 mL PS and 50 mL aniline with the same pHs were prepared before the reaction. The reaction was initiated after mixing the above suspension and solutions, and the final concentrations of CuO, PS and aniline were 1.0 g L−1, 2.3 mM and 1.2 mM, respectively. The conical flasks were placed in a temperature-controlled at shaker (25 ± 1 °C) with the rotating speed of 150 rpm. Samples were taken out at regular intervals during the reaction and then were centrifuged. The supernatant was then used to analyze the residual concentration of aniline. After reaction, the insoluble pellets were collected and washed with 5.0 M HCl and DI water in sequence to obtain the insoluble oxidation products. The insoluble oxidation products were then freeze-dried for 12 h and stored for future characterizations. All experiments were carried out in duplicate, and the average values with the corresponding standard deviations being presented. 2.4 Analysis and characterizations A spectrophotometric method described previously was used for the analysis of aniline concentrations [38]. The concentrations of PS were determined by detecting the absorbance of a yellow product formed in the reaction between PS and KI at 352 nm with a UV spectrometer [39,40]. The oxidation intermediates during the reaction were identified by a UV–vis absorption spectra. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS, Agilent 5975C) was also used to determine the molecular structure of the oxidation intermediates with CH2Cl2 as the extractant. During the extraction process, the aqueous samples were mixed thoroughly with CH2Cl2. After that, the CH2Cl2 phase was taken out and concentrated at 40 °C by vacuum evaporation [41]. The GC–MS equipment was pre-heated through a temperature-programmed route from 50 to 270 °C with a heating rate of 54 °C min−1, and the analysis was carried out at 70 eV using a HP-5MS cross-linked 5 % PH ME siloxane capillary column [42]. The oxidizing radicals in the CuO-PS system were qualitatively identified by an electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR, Bruker, EMX 10/12). The OH, SO4 − and carbon-centered radicals (CCRs) were trapped by DMPO and 1O2 was captured by TMP. The functional groups in the solid products were identified by a Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy with a KBr pressed disk as the matrix (FTIR, Bruker optics). The molecular compositions of the solid products were determined by a nuclear magnetic resonance at room temperature (1H NMR, 400 MHz). To characterize the molecular weight distribution of PA-7 (the insoluble oxidation products at pH 7.0) and PA-12 (the insoluble products at pH 12.0), we dissolved the products in methanol (solubility<5%). Given that the solubility of PA-7 cannot meet the detection requirement of the MALDI-TOF-MS spectrum, we only characterize the molecular weight distribution of PA-12 with the matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF-MS) with the use of 337 nm laser. TG-DTG measurement of the solid products was also carried out by the thermogravimetric analyzer TG 209 F3 Tarsus (Netzsch) from 25 °C to 900 °C in N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Electrochemical measurements were recorded at room temperature on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation (Chenhua, China). In the electrochemical analysis, a three electrode system was used to test the electrochemical properties of the solid products. The working electrode was prepared by mixing acetylene black, PANI and binder PVDF with the ratio of 8:1:1 dissolved in NMP. After that, the slurry was coated on one side of the ITO conducting glass with the area of 1 cm × 1 cm. The platinum sheet and the Ag/AgCl electrode were selected as the respective counter and reference electrodes. Three electrodes were then placed in a 0.5 M Na2SO4 electrolyte to keep the electrodes on the same horizontal surface. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) analysis was carried out at the scanning rates of 5−100 mV s−1 in the potential region of −0.4−0.4 V. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis was conducted by using an open circuit potential of 1.32 V with the frequency range of 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Oxidation kinetics of aniline under different pHs To investigate the removal efficacies of aniline under neutral and alkaline conditions, we selected pHs 7.0 and 12.0 as typical pHs to carry out removal kinetics of aniline. The control experiments show negligible removal of aniline at pHs 7.0 and 12.0 in the absence of PS (Fig. 1 ), indicating that adsorption of aniline on CuO does not contribute to aniline removal. Meanwhile, the oxidation of aniline in the absence of CuO shows that aniline can be directly oxidized by PS, with the corresponding rate constants (k obs) of 7.8 × 10−3 and 6.4 × 10−3 min−1 at pHs 7.0 and 12.0, indicating the contribution of the Boyland-Sims reaction to aniline oxidation [43]. In the presence of CuO and PS, 1.2 mM aniline was rapidly removed by the CuO-PS system in 30 min at pHs 7.0 and 12.0 (Fig. 1) with the corresponding k obs values of 9.71 × 10-2 and 2.94 × 10-1 min-1, suggesting the high reactivity of CuO and PS in the oxidation of aniline. The initial pH on the removal efficacy of aniline was also investigated. With increasing pHs from 5.0 to 12.0, 1.2 mM aniline can be rapidly removed with k obs values increasing from 9.01 × 10−2 to 2.94 × 10−1 min−1 (Table 1 and Fig. S3), indicating that solution OH- facilitates the oxidation of aniline. Fig. S4 shows the reusability of CuO in repeated oxidation of aniline. After five cycles, 88 % of 1.2 mM aniline could still be removed after 150 min (Table S1), implying the high reactivity of CuO in repeated oxidation processes. The high consumption ratios of PS and aniline have been reported previously, namely, 10 in the BiFeO3 nanoparticles-PS system, 9 in the rice straw biochar-PS system and 42 in the copper-nickel binary oxysulfide-PS system [44–46]. In order to investigate the oxidation efficacy of the CuO-PS system, we also determined the consumption ratio of PS and aniline during the oxidation processes. Eq. 1 shows that 18 mol PS is required for mineralizing 1 mol aniline to CO2 and H2O, whereas only 1.19 mol PS at pH 7.0 and 1.68 mol PS at pH 12.0 (Fig. 2 ). The large differences between the real values and the theoretical values indicate that mineralization of aniline to CO2 and H2O is not the primary pathway in the CuO-PS system. (1) C 6 H 7 N + 18 S 2 O 8 2 - + 37 O H - → 6 C O 2 + 22 H 2 O + 36 S O 4 2 - + N O 3 - After the oxidation of aniline, the supernatant were also collected for UV–vis analysis to identify soluble oxidation intermediates. The 230 and 280 nm peaks are characteristic bands of aniline [47,48], representing the corresponding absorption bands of amino and benzene ring. The apparent decreases of those two peaks imply the removal of aniline from the CuO-PS system at pH 7.0 (Fig. 3 a). Likewise, the peak intensities at 230 nm decrease with time at pH 12.0, however, the peak intensities at 280 nm increase with time (Fig. 3b), indicating polymerization of low-molar-mass PANI [49]. Additionally, we also observe increasing peak intensities at 430 nm at pHs 7.0 and 12.0 with time (Fig. 3), indicating formation of the azo bond (NN) during the oxidation processes [50]. 3.2 Different reactive oxygen species (ROS) involved in aniline oxidation We also carried out quenching experiments to investigate different ROS involved in aniline oxidation. SO4 − and OH are always believed the important ROS involved in the oxidation of various contaminants mediated by PS [27,51]. Considering that methanol can effectively scavenge the activities of SO4 − (k = 2.5 × 107 M−1s−1) [17] and OH (k = 9.7 × 108 M−1 s−1) [6], and TBA can quench the reactivity of OH (k = 6.0 × 108 M−1 s−1) but not SO4 − (k = 8.0 × 105 M−1 s−1) [6,17], we therefore used methanol and TBA to differentiate contributions of SO4 − and OH to aniline oxidation. To evaluate the contribution of O2 − to aniline oxidation, chloroform was used as an O2 − scavenger (k = 3.0 × 1010 M−1 s−1) [52]. In the presence of 1.0 M TBA, the respective k obs values at pHs 7.0 and pH 12.0 decrease slightly from 9.71 × 10-2 and 2.94 × 10-1 min-1 to 9.26 × 10-2 and 2.45 × 10-1 min-1 (Fig. S5, Table 1). Likewise, the oxidation rates of aniline are slightly inhibited by 1.0 M methanol with the corresponding k obs values of 9.69 × 10−2 and 1.51 × 10−1 min−1 at pHs 7.0 and pH 12.0. In the presence of 10 mM chloroform, the corresponding k obs values are 5.82 × 10−2 and 1.74 × 10−1 min−1 at pHs 7.0 and pH 12.0. This rules out the primary contributions of SO4 −, OH and O2 − to aniline oxidation by CuO and PS. We also used EPR to distinguish ROS in the CuO-PS system. DMPO can effectively capture OH, SO4 −, O2 − and CCR radicals [53,54], whereas TMP can capture 1O2 [55–57]. The absence of TMP-1O2 excludes the contribution of 1O2 to aniline oxidation (Fig. S6b). The presence of SO4 − and OH in EPR analysis suggests that SO4 − and OH are produced during the oxidation process (Fig. S6a). Meanwhile, the presence of CCRs in EPR analysis indicates formation of aniline radical cation (Fig. S6a), given the resonance structures between CCRs and the aniline radical cation [58]. After an electron is abstracted from aniline, aniline is converted to aniline radical cation. Likewise, our recent studies also observed formation of CCRs in the thiophene-CuO-PS and phenol-Co3O4-PS systems under neutral or alkaline conditions, and the presence of thiophene/phenol apparently increased the intensities of SO4 − and OH [28,29]. Venkataramanan et al. [59] also suggested that aniline radical cations could polymerize together, with the formation of dimers, oligomers and polymers. 3.3 The soluble and insoluble oxidation products The insoluble products were obtained after the oxidation products were treated by 5.0 M HCl. In the kinetic experiments, given that different oxidation behaviors of aniline at pHs 7.0 and 12.0, we assume that the insoluble oxidation products collected at pHs 7.0 (PA-7) and 12.0 (PA-12) may be different. Figs. S2b and S2c show small irregular morphology of PA-7 and PA-12, respectively. In the FTIR analysis of aniline, the peaks at 3444 and 3352 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of NH bond in aniline (Fig. 4 ) [60,61]. The peaks at 3033 and 1170 cm−1 represent the aromatic CH stretching and the aromatic CH in-plane bending vibrations, respectively [61]. The bands at 1606 and 1490 cm−1 are the aromatic CC stretching vibrations and the peak at 1278 cm-1 represents the stretching vibration of CN in aniline [60,61]. The peaks in the range of 900−650 cm−1 can be attributed to aromatic CH out-plane bending vibrations of aniline [62]. By contrast, the broad band around 3400 cm−1 in PA-7 and PA-12 represents the NH stretching of the secondary amine (-NH-), indicating that dehydrogenation of aniline occurs during the oxidation of aniline (Fig. 4) [63,64]. The 1593 cm−1 (PA-7) and 1590 cm−1 (PA-12) peaks are typical CC stretchings in the quinonoid ring (N = quinonoid = N) [62,65], indicating formation of quinonoid during the oxidation of aniline. The 1504 cm−1 (PA-7) and 1501 cm−1 (PA-12) peaks represent the benzenoid ring of N-benzenoid-N compounds [62,66]. The high contents of CC/CC and CN/CN in PA-7 (83.6 %) and PA-12 (70.9 %) in XPS analysis further indicates the presence of aniline-like units in the insoluble oxidation products (Fig. S7 and Table S2). In addition, the corresponding shifts of aromatic CC stretching vibrations from 1606 cm−1 to 1593 (PA-7) and 1590 cm−1 (PA-12) and from 1490 cm−1 to 1504 (PA-7) and 1501 cm−1 (PA-12) reveal polymerization of aniline to PANI (Fig. 4). We also observe the shifts of the CN stretching vibrations from 1278 to 1315 (PA-7) and 1299 cm−1 (PA-12) (Fig. 4). The 1315 cm−1 band in PA-7 is attributed to the CN stretching in the alternative units in the quinoid-benzenoid-quinoid rings and the 1299 cm−1 peak is attributed to the CN stretching in the secondary aromatic amine [62,65,67], indicating different structures of PA-7 and PA-12, namely, more quinonoid rings in PA-7 and more benzenoid rings in PA-12. In addition, the increasing intensities and shifts of the aromatic CH in-plane from 1170 to 1160 (PA-7) and 1162 cm−1 (PA-12) imply the increasing occurrence of linear structures (Fig. 4), indicating that aniline has been polymerized to PANI [68]. Meanwhile, the bending vibrations of aromatic C–H at 881 cm−1 are red-shifted to 831 (PA-7) and 821 cm−1 (PA-12), confirming the occurrence of head-to-tail coupling of aniline during the oxidation process [68]. In order to investigate the conversion yields of aniline to PANI in the CuO-PS system at pHs 7.0 and 12.0, we collected PA-7 and PA-12 after reaction and observed that the corresponding insoluble oxidation products of PA-7 and PA-12 are 138.5 and 197.3 mg (3.6 mM aniline in 750 mL solution is 251.75 mg), suggesting that 78.5 % and 55.1 % of aniline has been converted to PANI at pHs 7.0 and 12.0, respectively. This again confirms that aniline was not completely mineralized to CO2 and H2O. The insoluble oxidation products PA-7 and PA-12 were also dissolved in DMSO-d6 , and actually, less than 10 % of the oxidation products can be dissolved in DMSO with a large fraction of undissolved residuals. The dark solutions were then obtained and used for 1H NMR analysis. Fig. S8 shows two broad peaks in the range of 8.35−6.74 ppm and 8.05−6.55 ppm in the 1H NMR spectra of PA-7 and PA-12. The peaks around 7.0 ppm and in the range of 8.0–8.6 ppm represent the corresponding aromatic CH and NH bands [35,69], implying the presence of aromatic CH and NH in the oxidation products. In addition, the peaks in the range of 2.10−0.66 ppm represent the presence of aliphatic CH in the insoluble oxidation products [70], indicating the breaking of some aniline rings. In the MALDI-TOF-MS analysis, the peak-to-peak distance of 91 confirms the presence of -C6H4-NH- repeated units in the dissolved products (Fig. 5 ) [71], which is also consistent with the FTIR results (Fig. 4). According to the reference described previously, the m/z values of the dissolved products can be accurately expressed as 91n (repeat units) +1.0 (H), where n is the number of repeat units [72]. The molecular weight distribution of 728.67–1546.25 in PA-12 reveals the polymerization degree of 17 in the dissolved products. However, as to the undissolved residuals, their molecular weight distribution cannot be determined yet. To explore the composition of soluble products in the CuO-PS-aniline system, we used GC–MS to analyze the supernatant after extracting the soluble oxidation products by CH2Cl2 (Figs. 6 and 7 ). Three primary soluble products in total ion chromatogram (TIC) of the supernatant can be detected at pH 7.0. Peaks 1, 2 and 3 at 14.87, 16.20 and 17.23 min in Fig. 6a represent the corresponding azobenzene (89.39 %), phenazine (8.96 %) and azoxybenzene (1.65 %) at pH 7.0 (Fig. 6). By contrast, soluble products at pH 12.0 are similar to those at pH 7.0, azobenzene, and phenazine can also be detected in Fig. 7a. Peaks 1, 2 and 3 at 14.87, 16.21 and 18.36 min in Fig. 7a indicate the presence of azobenzene (76.63 %), phenazine (7.77 %) and benzenediamine (15.60 %) at pH 12.0 (Fig. 7). The presence of such soluble products in GC–MS analysis further demonstrate the presence of aniline radical cation and CCRs in the oxidation systems before the polymerization of aniline. 3.4 Mechanisms in the oxidation of aniline Non-radical pathways involved in PS activation on various metal oxides and carbon materials have been suggested, and the OO bond is moderately elongated, instead of breaking into sulfate radicals, when PS adsorbs on the catalysts [29]. Quenching experiments (Fig. S5) as well as EPR analysis (Fig. S6) also indicate that PS is activated on CuO via the non-radical pathway and confirm the important intermediates of PhNH2 + and the corresponding CCRs during the oxidation of aniline. The soluble products in UV and GCMS analyses confirm the presence of azobenzene, phenazine, azoxybenzene and benzenediamine in aniline oxidation (Figs. 3, 6 and 7), implying subsequent abstraction of H+ from PhNH2 + and the important intermediates of PhNH radicals. A series of solid characterizations further reveal that insoluble PANI is the primary oxidation product at pHs 7.0 and 12.0. The oxidation mechanisms can therefore be summarized as follows: (i) PS is activated on CuO via the non-radical pathway; (ii) the activated PS grabs an electron from aniline with the production of PhNH2 + and CCRs, followed by subsequent abstraction of a H+ from PhNH2 + by OH− with the formation of PhNH ; (iii) PhNH radicals couple to form soluble azobenzene, phenazine and azoxybenzene at pH 7.0, and soluble azobenzene, phenazine and benzenediamine at pH 12.0; (iv) aniline dimers further couple to form oligomers and then insoluble PANI polymers (Scheme 1 ). 3.5 Possible applications of the solid products TG-DTG analysis was used to analyze the thermochemical properties of PA-7 and PA-12. Fig. 8 shows that the TG curves of PA-7 and PA-12 exhibit two-step weight losses. The first step (40−372 °C in PA-7; 40−387 °C in PA-12) results from H2O evaporation and small molecule decomposition [73–75]. The second step (372−690 °C in PA-7; 387-690 °C in PA-12) corresponds to the decomposition of high molecular-weight polymers [74,75]. T i (the temperature at the start of DTG curve with regard to the second-step weight loss) and T p (the temperature at the minimum peak of DTG curve with regard to the second-step weight loss) are two criteria to determine the thermal stability of polymers, and the larger T i and T p values always imply the higher thermal stability of the polymer [76,77]. Given that both T i and T p values of PA-7 are lower than those of PA-12 (Fig. 8a), the thermally stability of PA-12 is higher than that of PA-7. Qi et al. [78] also prepared PANI with the corresponding T i and T p of 297 °C and 405 °C, indicating the higher thermal stability of PA-7 and PA-12. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) analysis was used to compare the electrochemical properties of PA-7 and PA-12. The analysis was carried out a three-electrode system with 0.5 M Na2SO4 as the electrolyte. The prominent redox peaks in the CV curves indicate the reversible oxidation and reduction of PA-7 (Fig. 9 a). With increasing scanning rates, the peak intensities of PA-7 increase accordingly and the shapes of CV curves show negligible changes (Fig. 9a), revealing the ideal pseudo-capacitive property and the fast charge-discharge performance for electrochemical energy storage [79]. By contrast, the CV curves of PA-12 show near-rectangular shapes and no evident redox peak can be readily observed (Fig. 9b), which indicates the ideal pseudo-capacitive behaviors of PA-12 with highly reversibility [80]. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis was also conducted to explore the electrochemical performances of the polyaniline electrodes. Fig. S9 shows the Nyquist plots of PA-7 and PA-12. The corresponding equivalent series resistances of polyaniline are 3.79 and 8.25 Ω of PA-7 and PA-12 (Fig. S9). Chaudhari et al. [81] also synthesized PANI with the resistance of 10.5 Ω. The lower resistance values in PA-7 and PA-12 indicate that they are appropriate for supercapacitor. 4 Conclusions In this work, CuO and PS show high oxidation reactivity toward aniline in pH-neutral and alkaline environments. The increased k obs values with increasing pHs indicate the importance of OH− in aniline oxidation. In addition, the low ratios between the removed PS and aniline (1.19 at pH 7.0 and 1.68 at pH 12.0) indicate the high efficiency and cost performance of the CuO-PS system in aniline oxidation. The insignificant contributions of SO4 −, OH, 1O2 and O2 − to aniline oxidation indicate that PS is likely activated on the surface of CuO via the non-radical pathway. The presence of CCRs and the soluble products of azobenzene, phenazine, azoxybenzene and benzenediamine in UV and GCMS analysis, as well as PANI polymers in the solid oxidation products (PA-7 and PA-12), confirm the important intermediates of PhNH2 + and PhNH radicals in the oxidation process. In this regard, separate transfer of an electron from aniline to form PhNH2 + by activated PS, followed by abstraction of a H+ from PhNH2 + to PhNH by OH are therefore two important steps in the oxidation process. Further coupling of PhNH radicals results in insoluble PANI polymers. Both PA-7 and PA-12 exhibit high thermal stability and ideal pseudo-capacitive properties, indicating that the PANI produced from aniline wastewater can be used for high-temperature-resistant materials or capacitors. Compared with the conventional activation of PS to SO4 −, the non-radical activation of PS in this study can more selectively oxidize aniline to polyaniline under alkaline conditions. In addition, the low molar ratios of PS: aniline (1.19 at pH 7.0 and 1.68 at pH 12.0) compared with those in previous studies also indicate the high oxidation efficiency of PS and CuO. This study opens a new door for turning aniline wastes from wastewater into value-added PANI. How to more efficiently bond the aniline wastes into uniform PANI polymers with better electrochemical properties and higher thermal stability is the interest of our future work. coredata.dc:description: Although the oxidation processes mediated by persulfate (PS) and peroxymonosulfate (PMS) attract more attention in the degradation of various recalcitrant contaminants, the high concentrations of oxidants required for the low concentrations of contaminants always limit their large-scale applications. In this work, aniline can be effectively oxidized by CuO and PS under pH-neutral and alkaline conditions. The increased observed rate constant (k obs) values with increasing pHs indicate that the oxidation of aniline is facilitated by solution OH−. Meanwhile, the low ratios between the removed PS and aniline (1.19 at pH 7.0 and 1.68 at pH 12.0) indicate the high catalytic oxidation efficacy of the CuO-PS system. The insignificant contributions of SO4 −, OH, 1O2 and O2 − to aniline oxidation in quenching experiments and EPR analysis suggest that PS is likely activated on the surface of CuO via the non-radical pathway. The presence of carbon-centered radicals (CCRs), as well as UV and GCMS analysis, indicates the important intermediates of PhNH2 + and PhNH radicals during the oxidation process, revealing that separate transfer of an electron from aniline to the activated PS, followed by subsequent abstraction of a H+ by OH− to form PhNH are two important steps in the oxidation process. Further coupling of PhNH radicals results in the formation of insoluble polyaniline polymers at pHs 7.0 and 12.0. The high thermal stability and ideal pseudo-capacitive properties of the insoluble products indicate that the polyaniline produced from aniline wastewater can be used for high-temperature-resistant materials or capacitors. This study provides an efficient alternative to turn aniline waste to polyaniline polymers.
coredata.dc:title: Conversion of aniline contaminant to valuable polyaniline polymers from wastewater under alkaline conditions
